discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
Looks like issue is on SQL applying stage. Therefore DE

Selected Answer: BD
Missing the primary key on the slave always causes the big events to replicate/apply slowly as it needs to do a full table scan due to missing primary index. So B & D

comments.content: B & D, I think C may be a possible answer, but I have to think about it.

discussion.content:
Not A. The thread is normally very fast and a master can have multiple slaves. 
Tables not having primary keys can cause replication slowness. 
I have seen a master execute many queries in parallel but a slave executes them serially.

Selected Answer: AD
The correct answers are:

A. The master is most probably too busy to transmit data and the slave needs to wait for more data.
D. The master is producing a large volume of events in parallel but the slave is processing them serially.

Explanation:

A. When the "Seconds_Behind_Master" value is steadily growing, it indicates that the slave is falling behind the master because it's waiting for data from the master. This can happen if the master is busy and cannot transmit data to the slave as quickly as the slave can process it.

D. If the master is producing a large volume of events (changes) in parallel, but the slave is processing them serially (one by one), it can lead to a situation where the slave falls behind the master. The slave might not be able to keep up with the incoming changes, causing the "Seconds_Behind_Master" value to increase.

choices.A: The master is most probably too busy to transmit data and the slave needs to wait for more data.
choices.C: This value shows only I/O latency and is not indicative of the size of the transaction queue.
choices.E: The parallel slave threads are experiencing lock contention.
choices.D: The master is producing a large volume of events in parallel but the slave is processing them serially.
choices.B: One or more large tables do not have primary keys.

questions.question_text:
Examine the modified output:
//IMG//

Seconds_Behind_ Master value is steadily growing.
What are two possible causes? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
root@localhost[shop]> select * from performance_schema.variables_by_thread where VARIABLE_NAME='sort_buffer_size';
+-----------+------------------+----------------+
| THREAD_ID | VARIABLE_NAME | VARIABLE_VALUE |
+-----------+------------------+----------------+
| 66 | sort_buffer_size | 262144 |
| 67 | sort_buffer_size | 262144 |
+-----------+------------------+----------------+
2 rows in set (0.00 sec)

Selected Answer: C
variables_by_thread: Session system variables for each active session. An application that wants to know the session variable values for specific sessions should use this table. It includes session variables only, identified by thread ID.

questions.question_text:
You want to check the values of the sort_buffer_size session variables of all existing connections.
Which performance_schema table can you query?

discussion.content: bkackhole does not. tested. MEMORY doesn't rollback, so its MyISAM, ARCHIVE, and MEMORY

Selected Answer: BEF
B. ARCHIVE - This engine is for storing large amounts of data without indexes in a very small footprint. It does not support transactions, so the INSERT would not be rolled back.

comments.content: blackhole is only meant to record data in the binlog. It wlll always succeed but never record data in the database,

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AEF
Blackhole will show data

questions.question_text:
Examine this command, which executes successfull
mysqlbackup --defaults-file=/backups/server-my.cnf --backup-dir=/backups/full copy-back
Which statement is true about the copy-back process?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A is wrong

choices.A: The copy-back process is used to overwrite a new backup over an existing backup.
choices.D: The copy-back process makes inconsistent backups.
choices.C: It restores files from the backup directory to their original MySQL server locations.
choices.B: It restores files from the data directory to their original MySQL server locations.

questions.question_text: Which three actions are effective in capacity planning? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: BFG, all has to do with predicting, and you need to monitor stuff and ask what is going to happen in the future by developers.

choices.F: basing expected growth on an average of the last 3 years
choices.C: adding circular replication nodes for increased DML capability
choices.G: consulting the application team about any future projects and use
choices.H: upgrading to the latest application version
